body:
BUMP. I am with you. Really need this feature.

For security reason, it is good idea to bind node to an internal network interface, but it also disables "localhost". Replication which refers to "localhost" stops working and you probably cannot refer single node for replication (how does replicated "replication document" work in reality???)
PRs welcome :)
First RFC is up here: https://github.com/apache/couchdb-documentation/pull/424
Thanks everyone for the feedback. I'm updated this PR based on the feedback.
@nickva Tests pass on Jenkins. Let me know if you want me to rebase.
@wohali any inputs from you on the above issues?

Also I see this warning during compiling/make:-
`Warning: erlang:now/0: Deprecated BIF. See the "Time and Time Correction in Erlang" chapter of the ERTS User's Guide for more information.`
Could this be related to the timeouts?
No and no.

Thanks for reporting the issue, @maciozo 

I tried installing erlang 22 and elixir build on erlang 22 locally with asdf

```
$ asdf current
elixir         v1.8.2-otp-22 (set by ASDF_ELIXIR_VERSION environment variable)
erlang         22.0.5   (set by ASDF_ERLANG_VERSION environment variable)
```

Then did `git clean -xffd` to clean all current build artifacts, added 22 to rebar.conf.script in main repo and for snappy dependency and got `make eunit` and `make elixir` tests to pass.

Created a PR to update snappy:
 https://github.com/apache/couchdb-snappy/commit/0f73f2b1b3508c31dd1129e2d7233ff9a469c775

And then one update the main repo with that new snappy version and bumped rebar.config.script values:
 https://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/2070

Though that also required bumping elixir from 1.6.6. to 1.7.4
Just built from erlang-22-support. Fauxton reports a good installation!

@nickva could you be sure to update apache/couchdb-ci to bump the minimum version of Elixir required to 1.7.4? Thanks.

One line fix: https://github.com/apache/couchdb-ci/blob/master/bin/install-elixir.sh#L31

@wohali thanks for the reminder!

https://github.com/apache/couchdb-ci/pull/22

Interesting 22.0 build got a segfault crash in Travis:

```
fabric_doc_open:324: t_handle_message_reply...Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

Locally it ran with 22.0.5, so let's try that in .travis.yml file

@rnewson @wohali 

By no means am I a regular maintainer of CouchDB, but it sounds like this particular issue would be resolved best by adding some documentation explaining to users how they would "disable" a user using one of the methods described above. 

The only thing then that would be needed would be the returning of a special error code, but that could be done perhaps on the client side? If done on the `derived_key` the client could manually inspect the derived key for the disable character, e.g. `!`, and manually show an error with the correct message to the user. 

If this works I can open a PR to make the update in the documentation.

Documentation PR as well:

https://github.com/apache/couchdb-documentation/pull/425
I had noticed `_local_docs` and `_design_docs` don't return local and design docs (respectively), but return all docs currently. But I think those are not in scope of the PR?

Another observation is `update_seq=true` only works for `POST _all_docs` + `{keys : [...]}` but not for regular `GET _all_docs?update_seq=true`. Master currently returns an update sequence for `GET` as well.

So I think it's just a matter of adding `{update_seq, null}` here somewhere https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/490cf197798571e8600d06819446fe222052cc2f/src/chttpd/src/chttpd_db.erl#L849

For `_local_docs` and `_design_docs` I haven't yet reimplemented the logic to make those work. Theoretically those will be straight forward but I wasn't overly concerned at this point since they're not needed for replication.
Also, I fixed the update_seq logic.

And it returns actual `update_seq' values even:

```
...
    ],
    "total_rows": 4,
    "update_seq": "00000005a7a62ff600000000"
}
```
Part of this merged with #2037 .

Shard splitting landed in #1920 and related. Shard merging does not yet exist, but the shard splitting gives us most of the infrastructure necessary to make it happen.

We still lack tools to visualise node balancing.
Cloudant contributed their version to CouchDB here: #1910

@tabeth This was also on the `dev@couchdb.apache.org` mailing list - concerns were raised that it could break session-based replication (a performance improvement introduced in 2.2.0). There are ways to solve it, but we can't forget that important use case. Also, every single client library that uses `_session` today will need rewriting to grab a new cookie -- so this breaks reverse compatibility.

Linking here for reference: https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/13d9fbce563f2858a317680c9b40e2542085835c628b4dff40576601@%3Cdev.couchdb.apache.org%3E

And linking your thread on this in April for completeness:

https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/75397c875e5791eee9b20aed5e7e1c2337d3ee0b94a5fb260ad39eac@%3Cdev.couchdb.apache.org%3E

Finally, a competing proposal: see #844 .

Can I ask - you say "We want" in your proposal. Who's "we"? :wink:
@dch mentions QuickJS Javascript Engine (https://bellard.org/quickjs/) - from bellard, supports es2019.

@wohali 

Thanks for that first link, very helpful! So I took a look at the pull request referenced there and my thoughts are two fold:

1. If this change is accepted we (I can take the lead on this) make a change in Fauxton to something similar @janl recommended in the thread, w.r.t. a modal that allows one to login again without losing their progress, or similar. 

2. We would need to document that enabling this will result in a decrease in performance as replicator session refresh would fallback to the periodic "hard" refresh. 

As for an implementation, tentatively I'm thinking (this is pretty naive, though):


(in `couchdb/src/chttpd/src/chttpd.erl`)
```erlang

basic_headers(Req, Headers0) ->
    Headers = Headers0
        ++ server_header()

  % psuedocode
   case config:get_boolean("chttpd", "include_refresh_auth_session", true) || Map.get(Req, path_parts) == <<"_session">> of
     true ->  Headers = Headers ++ couch_httpd_auth:cookie_auth_header(Req, Headers0)
    Headers1 = chttpd_cors:headers(Req, Headers),
	Headers2 = chttpd_xframe_options:header(Req, Headers1),
    chttpd_prefer_header:maybe_return_minimal(Req, Headers2).
```
/cc @nickva @mikerhodes can you please review and comment?
I would like to mention [Rustler](https://github.com/rusterlium/rustler) for safe NIFs to reduce chances of crashing BEAM VM.

@chintan-mishra good to know, but that doesn't help specifically for JavaScript embedding. Erlang -> Rust -> JS just means twice the symbol marshalling, which is already our performance bottleneck. And I'm not about to reimplement a JS interpreter in Rust... ;)

As far as the replicator, yeah we could document that it might do extra _session requests. We had switched to make `allow_peristent_cookies = true` to be the default not too long ago https://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/1619 which also includes the logic to forcibly refresh the session in the replicator.

One thing to worry about as @wohali have mentioned is about clients which rely only on auto-refresh. They'd have to implement a logic similar to what the replicator uses. I mentioned it in the ML linked but I'll paste it below as well for completeness:

> To review, currently a cookie refresh in the replicator happens in these
cases:
> 1) Auth / Authorization requests fail. Then we try to get a new session
cookie from _session. With auto-refresh this is not that used I imagine. It
does involve making an extra request (make original request, fail, refresh
cookie, retry request). And also this doesn't work if endpoints allow
anonymous writes.
> 2) max-age in the cookie value is about to expire (over 90% expired). We
also enabled allow_persistent_cookie=true by default, as you mentioned, so
most recent endpoints  should send max-age now. Without auto-refresh this
would hopefully become the best method to do refresh.
> 3) If max-age cannot be parsed we still get a new cookie at close to
default expiry interval for CouchDB (550 seconds) This accounts for
endpoints which haven't upgraded to the latest release, but just happened
to have session expiry defaults (600 seconds).
> 4) Response headers return a new session cookie. In that case we'd
remember the cookie as the new session cookie. But if we decide not to do
that anymore. In that case the other 3 conditions would hopefully be enough
to perform the refresh.


An interesting thing to think about is if this behavior could somehow be signaled by the server. In the welcome message (as a feature), or a cookie attribute `...; Autorefresh=False; ...`? So clients in the future would know to force refresh before expiration.

I did see that comment. My understanding is that the replicator would still get a new cookie per (3) right? I could be misunderstanding what you meant, though.

Another thing I was thinking about along the lines of your last comment is the inclusion of a "false" cookie that has an expiration but a invalid/blank AuthSession value. The idea there would be that a consumer would have to know that the cookie expiring in this case means they have to manually populate the AuthSession.

I mainly mentioned what the replicator does to highlight that other clients might have to be updated to do something similar.

Even 3) is not a 100% solution because if max-age is not sent (say it's an older CouchDB server), there is no way for the client to know the expiry time of the cookie. We assume it will be the default but we don't really know.

The case of anonymous writes highlighted in https://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/1619#issue-217349651 is something worth considering. That's the case where the server doesn't send a `Set-Cookie` header and the clients keep using the expired value. If anonymous writes are allowed, authentication doesn't fail (no 401 error) and a VDU function is used to control access based on authenticated username.

So overall, it seems like it could work. The "false" cookie feels like a hack (though it might work). Maybe we instead we always force `allow_persistent_cookie=true` if the new feature is enabled as well and let clients use `max-age` field for refreshes. I had suggest a custom cookie attribute that explicitly signals to clients that cookies won't auto-refresh, but have no idea how common or supported the idea of custom cookie attributes are...  But otherwise it seems like the new option might work and it would be useful in many contexts (and we also update Fauxton to handle auth failures and refreshes better).

We might need more eyes on this issue (@rnewson, @janl) in general.
@wohali that mention was in regard to Deno for JS engine.
@chintan-mishra got it, but see Paul's comment: https://github.com/apache/couchdb/issues/1884#issuecomment-485490716

I iterated on that and ended up with the version in https://github.com/apache/couchdb/commit/015fe58c71555553e913cc40cdb9713aefe5fea3. Unfortunately that encountered a latent bug in the logic around allocating a new buffer when we need to return values larger than 64 characters and it would segfault the VM. Thanks to @davisp for sorting out the fix for that issue in https://github.com/apache/couchdb/commit/33046b6cd38d550aab8780c9356105ee1891f98a. This code is wrapped up and has been brought into the `prototype/fdb-layer` branch in https://github.com/apache/couchdb/commit/f4e75ed32e32f4685a11f993ae416b5b47a719f7. Closing this out.

Also I found out that v8 itself isn't single threaded. Just Node.js's use of v8 so I've been wrong on that for quite some time. On the other hand I've also discovered that apparently most projects that use v8 end up vendoring a copy and building it as part of the build chain rather than re-use standard OS packages. So while v8 might be a usable engine its got a pretty terrible dependency story given the ASF process.

I'm fairly intrigued by that QuickJS project but given its only about two weeks old I'm a bit hesitant to pursue it very far. Seems almost too magically awesome given the relative size of other implementations both in team size and code size.

I think modern spidermonkey is equally fine, it should be relatively straightforward to port our bindings to the new API for someone more fluent in C/++ than I am, but given enough time even I think I could get it done which means it can't be that hard. It's just a rather thankless job.

I'm grabbing the SM modernisation effort, working off of @janl 's work to date. It's a "would be nice" for 3.0, but it comes after a bunch of other work on my pile right now (like improvements and bugfixes to docker and the packaging.)

Let's keep this ticket for non-SM stuff. The SM update ticket is #1875.
I'm also having this issue. @raoyitao did you find workaround/fix? :)

I had this issue as well. CouchDB 2.3.1

Strangely, I was unable to log out as well, when it happens. In Fauxton, I noticed that there was a database that was "unable to load" even though I was logged into Fauxton.

As far as I can tell, it had something to do with per_user databases getting in a weird state; I'm not entirely sure how I got there.  I was messing with permissions on the _users DB and that perhaps I caused it (I was creating users from another _users account.)  Either a user hadn't been properly deleted (somehow) or some kind of conflict between userdb- and the corresponding username.

My fix was from Fauxton,  find the userdb-xyz database that "cannot be loaded" and manually issue a DELETE from curl, Postman, (or tool of your choice.) I used Basic auth for this DELETE command, using my administrator user/pw.
Once that "Cannot be loaded" DB was gone, everything started working again. Luckily this was a local dev DB and I didn't need the contents of the userdb.

UPDATE: Also realized I had some dead nodes from playing with clustering before--this is perhaps why I was seeing the "cannot load DB".  http://localhost:5984/_membership showed 3 nodes even though I was intending to run just 1. I followed this to axe the extra ones. BE VERY CAREFUL WITH THIS- it can potentially delete data if you axe the wrong cluster, it appears. https://docs.couchdb.org/en/master/cluster/nodes.html

Thanks @wohali.  I posted in Slack and will update the issue if anyone there is able to help.

This is not a CouchDB bug. GitHub is for actual CouchDB bugs only. I believe your problem is invalid JavaScript in one of your views causing the external couchjs process to fail.

If you are looking for general support with using CouchDB, please try one of these other options:

Is the path to the installation one **without spaces**? Unfortunately, CouchDB cannot run in a subdirectory that has spaces (such as `C:\Program Files\CouchDB`.)
Yes, its c:/couchdb

Check the permissions on the directories. Can they be accessed by a non-admin user?

The installer sets very limited access by default on those directories. Specifically, non-admins are not allowed to write to those folders:

![MWSnap 2019-07-20, 18_07_44](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/112292/61584640-4adc6280-ab19-11e9-88f7-d090dd3656e4.png)

Double-check the permissions on all of the folders and ensure the user you wish to be able to run the program has full write access to the entire `C:\CouchDB` tree. Be sure to replace permissions on all sub-folders when changing these permissions.

**EDIT** Resolved, see below!

Hi there,

This is not a CouchDB bug. GitHub is for actual CouchDB bugs only. Nor is this a fully specced out RFC, I'm afraid.

If you are looking for general support with using CouchDB, please try one of these other options:

* The user mailing list. Signup instructions are [here](http://couchdb.apache.org/#mailing-lists)
* The Slack/IRC chat room. Joining instructions are [here](http://couchdb.apache.org/#chat)

> Our delayed commits option, is hard-coded to 1 second "only". And later fixes in the kernel do ensure that if we keep the FD open the error will be reported eventually.

Good extra info! I'm just glad, this is on the deprecation track already

For `close` I knew that was true but our algorithm is gated around fsync so I mostly ignored it. If we did get into the situation where we had written data but then closed before an fsync it'd be because we were shutting down. The lack of header write there would save us from any issues.

As for the "fsync will forget about errors" issue... well ain't that a kick in the pants? I agree there's not a whole lot we can do. Although I will have to say that given the length of time multiple popular databases have run on Linux without even a whisper of "fsync is totally broken" makes me think that actually encountering that particular issue in the wild is likely fairly miniscule.

Did you respond to the wrong ticket? I am extremely confused.

"Local" replications in CouchDB 2.x don't do what most users would expect them to do. 

It is mostly a legacy feature which is going to be removed in the next major release of CouchDB.

See this documentation PR for more details: https://github.com/apache/couchdb-documentation/pull/423

I'd follow @wohali's advice (who did reply to the right issue, btw) to use remote urls for source and target endpoints.

The reason you see "localhost:..." is that it was a patch / hack to make "local" replications work by transforming endpoints like "db" to a full url by using the ip and port the listening CouchDB server. That kind of / sort of works but not always and is somewhat surprising behavior.

OK, I know the problem.

DNS resolves all hostnames that end in `.localhost` to `127.0.0.1.`

Try it:

```
$ host foobar.localhost
foobar.localhost has address 127.0.0.1
foobar.localhost has IPv6 address ::1
```

This is why it's rewriting it as `127.0.0.1`.

Use a different hostname.

Fascinating! So then couchdb says "Well, now I'm doing local to local" and breaks the form?

Alright, if the fix is "find a better way to do this for development" then I can do that.
Although now that I think about it, it's weird that the UI/Form is incorrect despite the job still trying to reach docker.for.mac.localhost.

What Fauxton does is write the document, as you specify it, through to CouchDB.

It then reads that back when displaying the result.

CouchDB is rewriting the document, which is why you see what you see. :) And it does so in compliance with [RFC 2606](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2606) so I'm marking this as a wontfix.
